bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 27, 1900

div1.p: Reed mentions the houses constructed at the experimental camp. He describes the experimentation methods and plans. He anticipates a trip to Keewaydin in May.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 27, 1900
div1.p:
Last eve-
ning the wind came up from
the north-west, and my! how
it did blow all night- This
morning, the temperature stood
at 69° -- which with the hard
wind made one feel decid-
edly chilly, especially with
a short-sleeved gauze un-
der garment on. Now it
is blowing from the north
and promises to become much
colder to-night- I take it that
you have no longer, therefore,
any complaint about the
hot weather in Washington.
You must have had a lively
Zephyr to have given us
such a blow- I hope that it
hasn't increased the gouty
sensations in your darling
lame “footsey”- I didn't get
any letter from my sweet
Miss Gouty, yesterday, and
hence I haven't very late
news as to your general
state of health- Somehow
or other those letters of
yours are mailed on the
wrong day- But the fact
of the whole matter is that
the Post Office Department
is managed wretchedly here
in Havana- They don't trou-
ble themselves much about
a prompt distribution of
the incoming mail- Whenever
your darling letters come,
I enjoy them very much,
and I know that when one isn't
feeling well, its hard to
be writing letters- I guess
tomorrow I will get one
not only from precious
Miss Gout, but, also, from
bouncing Miss Silk Petty Coat!
To think that thanksgiving is
nearly here -- only day after
tomorrow -- and then Novem-
ber will have flown- I
sometimes get awfully im=
patient, but you know
that such a frame of mind
is nothing unusual with
your old Mr Teesigon! Don't
you, Miss Sweet Gouty?
I suppose that I ought to
feel satisfied with the prog-
ress made thus far with
my experimental station --
and in truth I am -- but
Cuban carpenters are so
slow & so much like American
carpenters, when they are
working by the day- I am having
two small houses constructed-
I don't know whether I have
told you this already -- one
for mosquito-bitten patients,
and the other for testing the
clothing infection theory -- but
I don't want to try the latter
until I have succeeded or
failed with the former. Another
week, I hope, will enable us
to tell what mosquitos can
do, as we now have some
insects that bit yellow
fever cases 10 days ago to-
day- If we can get them
to live 8 or 10 days more, I
believe we can reproduce the
disease promptly- I think
that if it required 12 days
in august to render the mos-
quitoes effective, it will take
18 to 24 days at this season-
This is, of course, only my opin-
ion, and I may be quite mis-
taken- I wrote the foregoing
part of this page at 3 o'clock,
this afternoon, and now it is
9.30 P.M. and I am sitting here
now in my overcoat with
doors & windows all closed
& lamp burning full-tilt.
The thermometer has fallen to
61°- I walked out on the porch
just now and what a perfectly
beautiful sky I found, with
the young moon hanging low
in the sky and the stars so
very bright- The clouds of
yesterday and to-day have
gone and the night is fas-
cinatingly beautiful- What
a wonderful winter-climate
this is, where frost never
comes; and yet what a
blessing a real hard
frost would be to this
Island. I wrote Johnnie
Moore a letter, this afternoon,
and told him how much
I appreciated the good
hard work that he had
put on that stone-fence.
I asked him to write to
me & tell me about the trees
&c- I guess that we don't
need to build any more stone-
fences for awhile, do we,
my sweetheart? How I long
for the spring-time and the month
of May to come, so that we
can go up and spend a week
at dear Keewaydin and plant
our garden and the flower-
beds that so gladden dear
Miss Gouty's heart! You
shall have beautiful flowers
next year, lovie, dear: and pre-
cious little scholar must have
a flower-bed too, for her
own darling little hands
to work and to keep the grass
cleanall pulled out- And then,
too, those grapes-vines should give
us many bunches, and those
berries- rasp, straw and
black -- should be quite
ausgezeichnete! Give my
kindest regards to Dr Nash
and tell him how much I ap-
preciate his services to you,
and that I would have written
to him, but have been so
very busy- Somehow I feel
sleepy, to-night, sweet oomsey,
and hence I am going to say
good-night to my sweet girls
and tumble into my little couch-
Boo! Boo! you darling, fat Joys!
Wednesday morning -- Nov. 28th.
Here I am, having overslept
myself, & I now hear the rattle
of the Postman's wagon
as he comes for the mail.
Boo! Boo! you precious loves.
Love & Kisses for my sweet
girls-
